awd_titl_txt: Optically-Driven Changes in Nanoparticle Solvation, Transport and Interaction
awd_abstract_narration:
Molecules within liquids organize themselves near solid surfaces in a range of different ways, a phenomenon called solvation. This organization plays a central role in important physical processes and technologies.  For example, solvation underlies the use of liquids as lubricants to minimize friction between two surfaces or to control the assembly of nanoparticles of metals (for example, gold) into advanced materials for sensing. The central role of solvation in determining the properties of solid-liquid interfaces has motivated many past efforts aimed at changing solvation.  Past efforts have included addition of salts to liquids or manipulation of temperature and pressure.  This project moves beyond past studies by investigating the use of visible light to optically excite and change solvation of metal surfaces.  The intensity and location at which light is delivered to a system can be readily manipulated, and thus the approach has the potential to make possible reversible and active control of solvation.  The successful outcome of this research may provide the basis of new energy-efficient separations processes or new ways to create materials for low-cost sensor networks. 

This project will elucidate how optical excitation of nanoparticles can change their solvation, transport properties and phase behavior.  The first thrust of research focuses on single nanoparticles, and elucidates how optical excitation of nanoparticles changes interfacial solvent structuring and thus nanoparticle hydrodynamic size. The second thrust of research examines how optically-induced changes in nanoparticle solvation alter pair-wise interactions, including electrical double layer and solvent-structural contributions.  Measurements of probability distance distribution functions for pairs of nanoparticles will be inverted to obtain potentials of mean force.  The third thrust of research investigates how optically-driven changes in nanoparticle solvation influence collective phenomena, such as the stability of dispersions of nanoparticles and their phase separation.  The overall outcome of this program of research will be new knowledge of fundamental transport and phase separation processes arising from optically-driven changes in nanoparticle solvation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The structuring of solvent molecules near interfaces influences a wide range of equilibrium and non-equilibrium phenomena, including by encoding interactions between colloidal species (e.g., hydrophobic interactions and critical Casimir forces).   The major goals of this project were to explore the use mesogenic solvents (solvents that can form liquid crystalline phases) to develop new ways to modulate solvent structuring and colloidal interactions.  One set of goals revolved around the use of optical excitation to impact solvent structuring near gold nanoparticles.  A second set of goals addressed the use of solvent structuring in liquid crystals to encode van der Waals interactions. 

Intellectual Merit: We pursued two major activities. First, we used single particle tracking methods to characterize changes in the hydrodynamic sizes of gold nanoparticles immersed in mesogenic solvents.   We used the measured changes in hydrodynamic size to quantify changes in interfacial solvation induced by illumination (optical excitation).Second, we polymerized liquid crystalline solvents, as microparticles and films, and measured the irreversible coagulation of probe particles across the surfaces of the liquid crystalline microparticles and films. We interpreted the rates of coagulation to quantify the van der Waals forces that encoded by the liquid crystalline solvent order. 

Two key outcomes emerged from this research. First, we obtained evidence that illumination of gold nanoparticles dispersed in liquid crystalline solvents can change the hydrodynamic sizes of the nanoparticles.  The effect depends on wave length of illumination and size of the nanoparticles, consistent with optical excitation of hot electrons within the nanoparticles.   We have also found that the influence of illumination varies strongly between nanoparticles, suggesting that surface heterogeneities (which are not yet fully understood) likely influence the magnitude of the effect. Second, we have demonstrated that control of liquid crystalline solvent order can be used to program van der Waals interactions in colloidal and interfacial systems. 

Broader Impacts: This project has generated fresh thinking regarding how light can impact solvation of nanoparticles and colloidal interactions.  Additionally, it has provided new methods to design van der Waals interactions via control of surface-induced orientations of liquid crystalline solvents. The ability to manipulate interfacial solvation and colloidal interactions has the potential to impact a range of disciplines, including disciplines focused clean water and sustainability. The research project also provided three graduate students with opportunities for professional development via participation in education and outreach events (e.g., Cornell University Splash Teacher Event; Ithaca Youth Bureau College Discovery mentors).
